tit.e: Sukiyaki (thin slices of beef, cooked with various vegetables in a table-top cast-iron pan)
tit.cmt: 「すき焼き」 補足説明の部分を変更しました。

sen.j: すき焼き（鋤焼、すきやき）は、肉を浅い鉄鍋で焼く (調理)、あるいは煮る料理。
sen.e: "Sukiyaki" is a dish of meat broiled (cooked) or boiled in a shallow cast-iron pot.
"Sukiyaki" is a dish consisting of meat that is broiled (cooked) or boiled in a shallow cast-iron pot.
"Sukiyaki" is a dish consisting of meat that is broiled (cooked) or boiled in a shallow cast-iron pot.

sen.j: 割下を用いた甘辛い味付けの料理の総称として「すき焼き風」という呼称も用いられる。
sen.e: The term "sukiyaki-fu" (sukiyaki-like cuisine) is used to mean collectively all dishes salted and sweetened by warishita (stock mixed with soysauce, mirin and sugar.)
The term "sukiyaki-fu" (sukiyaki style cuisine) refers to all dishes that are salted and sweetened by warishita (a stock made from a mixture of soy sauce, mirin and sugar.)

The term "sukiyaki-fu" (sukiyaki style cuisine) refers to all dishes that are salted and sweetened by warishita (a stock made from a mixture of soy sauce, mirin [sweet rice wine for cooking] and sugar).
sen.cmt: ピリオドを括弧の外に移動しました。みりん 補足説明を追加しました。

sen.j: 牛鍋（ぎゅうなべ）ともいう。
sen.e: It is also called "gyu-nabe" (a dish of beef cooked in a hot pot at the table.)
It is also called "gyu-nabe" (a dish of beef cooked in a hot pot at the table.)
It is also called "gyu-nabe" (a dish of beef cooked in a hot pot at the table).
sen.cmt: ピリオドを括弧の外に移動しました。

tit.cmt: コロンを削除しました。

sen.j: 一般的なすき焼きは薄切りにした牛肉が用いられ、ネギ、シュンギク、シイタケ、豆腐などの具材（ザクと呼ぶ）が添えられる。
sen.e: Generally, sliced beef is used for sukiyaki, with additional ingredients such as negi (a type of scallion), syungiku (garland chrysanthemum), shiitake mushroom, tofu (bean-curd) and so on.
Generally, sliced beef is used for sukiyaki, with additional ingredients such as negi (a type of scallion), syungiku (garland chrysanthemum), shiitake mushroom, tofu (bean-curd) and so on.
Generally, sliced beef is used for sukiyaki, with additional ingredients such as negi (a type of scallion), shungiku (garland chrysanthemum), shiitake mushroom, tofu (bean-curd) and so on.
sen.cmt: shungiku とスペルを変更しました。

sen.j: 味付けは醤油と砂糖が基本となる。
sen.e: Soybean sauce and sugar are used for basic seasoning.
Soybean sauce and sugar are used for basic seasoning.
Soybean sauce and sugar are used for basic seasoning.

sen.j: 鶏卵をからめて食べることもある。
sen.e: Sometimes, cooked ingredients are eaten together with beaten eggs of hen.
Sometimes, these cooked ingredients are eaten together with beaten eggs.
Sometimes, these cooked ingredients are eaten together with beaten eggs.

sen.j: しゃぶしゃぶの薄切り肉は熱湯にくぐらせるだけで食べられるほど薄いが、すき焼きの薄切り肉はしゃぶしゃぶに用いる肉よりも厚いことが多い。
sen.e: In most cases, beef for sukiyaki is sliced thicker than that for shabu-shabu (a dish of thinly sliced beef boiled with vegetables,) while beef for shabu-shabu is sliced so thinly as can be eaten after dipping it only once in hot water.

In most cases, beef for sukiyaki is sliced thicker than that for shabu-shabu (a dish of thinly sliced beef boiled with vegetables,) which is sliced so thinly that it can be eaten after being dipped only once in boiling water.

In most cases, beef for sukiyaki is sliced thicker than that for shabu-shabu (a dish of thinly sliced beef boiled with vegetables,) which is sliced so thinly that it can be eaten after being dipped only once in boiling water.

tit.cmt: コロンを削除しました。

sen.j: 日本では幕末になるまで、仏教の戒律などのため牛肉を食べることは一般には行われていなかったが、別に「すきやき」と称された料理は存在していた。
sen.e: Until the end of Edo Period in Japan, beef was not publicly eaten due to the precepts of Buddhism and other reasons, though there had existed other dishes with the same name "sukiyaki."
Until the end of Edo Period in Japan, beef was not commonly eaten due to the precepts of Buddhism as well as other reasons, however, there were still dishes referred to as "sukiyaki."
Until the end of Edo period in Japan, beef was not commonly eaten due to the precepts of Buddhism as well as other reasons, however, there were still dishes referred to as 'sukiyaki.'

sen.j: 古くは寛永20年（1643年）刊行の料理書『料理物語』に「杉やき」が登場している。
sen.e: In old times, a dish named "sugiyaki" was referred to in a cookbook "Ryori-monogatari" (a story of cooking) published in 1643.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: An old book published in 1643, titled "Ryori-monogatari" (a story of cooking) refers to a dish named "sugiyaki."
An old book published in 1643, titled "Ryori-monogatari" (a story of cooking) refers to a dish named 'sugiyaki.'
sen.cmt: 一部 "→ ' に変更しました。

sen.j: これは鯛などの魚介類と野菜を杉材の箱に入れて味噌煮にする料理である。
sen.e: This was a dish of fish and shellfish including sea bream, and vegetables, all of which were boiled in miso soup (soup of fermented soybean paste) in a box made of sugi material (Japanese cedar.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This was a dish of fish and shellfish, including sea bream, and vegetables, all boiled in miso soup (soup made from fermented soybean paste) in a box made of sugi material (Japanese cedar.)
This was a dish of fish and shellfish, including sea bream, and vegetables, all boiled in miso soup (soup made from fermented soybean paste) in a box made of sugi material (Japanese cedar).
sen.cmt: ピリオドを括弧の外に移動しました。

sen.j: さらに享和元年（1801年）の料理書『料理早指南』では、「鋤やき」は「鋤のうへに右の鳥類をやく也、いろかはるほどにてしょくしてよし」と記述されている。
sen.e: Futher, in another cookbook "Ryori-hayashinan" (literally, quick guidance for cooking) published in 1801, there was a description as below quoted:
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Furthermore, in another cookbook "Ryori-hayashinan" (literally, quick guidance for cooking) published in 1801, there is a description as quoted below:

Furthermore, another cookbook "Ryori-hayashinan" (literally, quick guidance for cooking) published in 1801, states that 'The term 'sukiyaki' refers to cooking birds' meat (as per mentioned on the right) by grilling it on the blade of a suki (a spade) until its color changes and it looks like it would taste good.'
sen.cmt: 一つにまとめ、英文もそのように修正しました。

sen.j: また、文化 (日本)元年（1804年）の『料理談合集』や文政12年（1829年）の『鯨肉調味方』にも具体的な記述が見られ、使い古した鋤を火にかざして鴨などの鶏肉や、あるいは鯨肉などを加熱する一種の焼肉であったことが判る。
sen.e: The other concrete descriptions about "sukiyaki" are seen in the books "Ryori-Dango-shu" (literally, collection of consultations on cooking) published in 1804 and "Geiniku-Chomi-kata" (literally, how to season whale meat) published in 1829, from which we can learn that sukiyaki dishes were cooked by broiling poulrty meat such as duck and chicken or other meat like whalemeat, on a heated blade of used spade over the fire.

Other concrete descriptions of "sukiyaki" exist in the books "Ryori-Dango-shu" (literally, collection of consultations on cooking) published in 1804, and "Geiniku-Chomi-kata" (literally, how to season whale meat) published in 1829, from which we can derive that sukiyaki dishes were cooked by broiling poultry meat such as duck and chicken or other meat like whale meat, on a heated spade over a fire.

Other concrete descriptions of sukiyaki exist in the books "Ryori-Dango-shu" (literally, collection of consultations on cooking) published in 1804, and "Geiniku-Chomi-kata" (literally, how to season whale meat) published in 1829, from which we can derive that sukiyaki dishes were cooked by broiling poultry meat such as duck and chicken or other meat like whale meat, on a heated spade over a fire.
sen.cmt: 一部ダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: この魚介類の味噌煮の「杉やき」と、鳥類・魚類の焼肉という「鋤やき」という二種類の料理が、牛肉の鍋物としての「すき焼き」の起源と言われている。
sen.e: These two kinds of cookings, namely "sugiyaki" as a dish of boiled fish and shellfish and "sukiyaki" as a dish of grilled meat of birds and fish, are regarded as the origins of current "sukiyaki" in the shape of nabemono of beef (one-pot cooking of beef served at the table.)

These two dishes, "sugiyaki" or boiled fish and shellfish, and "sukiyaki" or grilled birds and fish meat, are regarded as the origins of current day "sukiyaki" in the form of nabemono with beef (cooking beef in one large part at the table.)

These two dishes, 'sugiyaki' or boiled fish and shellfish, and 'sukiyaki' or grilled birds and fish meat, are regarded as the origins of current day 'sukiyaki' in the form of nabemono (a dish served in a pot at the table) with beef.
sen.cmt: 鍋物 補足説明を追加しました。

sen.j: なお、すき身の肉を使うことから「すき焼き」と呼ばれるようになったという説もある。
sen.e: Or otherwise, the name of sukiyaki is considered to have come from sukimi (scraped meats) used as ingredient.
Another theory is that the name of sukiyaki came from sukimi (scraped meats) being used as ingredients.
Another theory is that the name of 'sukiyaki' came from sukimi (scraped meats) being used as ingredients.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションを追加しました。

sen.j: 安政6年（1859年）に横浜港が開港すると、居留地の外国人が牛肉を欲しがり、地方から牛肉が運ばれるようになった（神戸市からと言われている）。
sen.e: In 1859, when the Yokohama Port was opened, lots of beef were brought in from rural areas (like Kobe as suggested) on behalf of foreigners living at enclaves who hankered for beef.
In 1859, when the Yokohama Port was opened, large quantities of beef were brought in from rural areas (such as Kobe) on behalf of foreigners living at enclaves who hankered for beef.
In 1859, when the Yokohama Port was opened, large quantities of beef were brought in from rural areas (such as Kobe) on behalf of foreigners living at enclaves who hankered for beef.

sen.j: このような状況で、文久2年（1862年）に横浜入船町で居酒屋を営んでいた伊勢熊（いせくま）が牛鍋屋を開業する。
sen.e: In the circumstances, a restaurant of gyu-nabe (a dish of beef cooked in a hot pot at the table) was launched in 1862 by an owner of a Japanese style pub, Isekuma, in the town of Irifune-cho, Yokohama.

Under these circumstances, a restaurant which served gyu-nabe (a beef dish cooked in a hot pot at the table) was established in 1862 by an owner of a Japanese style pub, Isekuma, in the town of Irifune-cho, Yokohama.
Under these circumstances, a restaurant which served gyu-nabe was established in 1862 by an owner of a Japanese style pub, Isekuma, in the town of Irifune-cho, Yokohama.
sen.cmt: 牛鍋 既出のため、補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 明治元年（1868年）、外国人向けに東京・芝に屠牛場ができた。
sen.e: In 1868, a cattle slaughterhouse was built to meet larger demands of foreigners for beef.
In 1868, a cattle slaughterhouse was built to meet larger demands of foreigners for beef.
In 1868, a cattle slaughterhouse was built to meet larger demands of foreigners for beef.

sen.j: 以降、東京でも牛鍋屋が流行し、以後牛食は文明開化の象徴となる。
sen.e: Since then, gyu-nabe restaurants became popular in Tokyo, and were regarded as a symbol of cultural enlightenment.
Since then, gyu-nabe restaurants became popular in Tokyo, and were regarded as a symbol of cultural enlightenment.
Since then, gyu-nabe restaurants became popular in Tokyo, and were regarded as a symbol of cultural enlightenment.

sen.j: 仮名垣魯文はこうした状況を『安愚楽鍋』（1871年）に描き出している。
sen.e: Such social situation was depicted in "Agura-nabe" a popular novel written in 1871 by Robun KANAGAKI (a writer of light literature late in the Edo Period.)
This shift in society was depicted in "Agura-nabe" a popular novel written in 1871 by Robun KANAGAKI (a writer of light literature late in the Edo Period.)
This shift in society was depicted in "Agura-nabe" a popular novel written in 1871 by Robun KANAGAKI (a writer of light literature late in the Edo period).
sen.cmt: period を小文字にしました。ピリオドを括弧の外に移動しました。

sen.j: この関東の「牛鍋」に対し、関西では先に焼いた牛肉を砂糖・醤油・出汁で調味する「すき焼き」が行われていた。
sen.e: At the same time as of the "gyu-nabe" in the Kanto region, the people of the Kansai region were taking "sukiyaki" in which beef was broiled before seasoning it with sugar, soybean sauce, and broth at the table.
At the same time "gyu-nabe" appeared in the Kanto region, the people of the Kansai region were making "sukiyaki" for which beef was broiled before seasoning it with sugar, soy sauce and broth.
At the same time 'gyu-nabe' appeared in the Kanto region, the people of the Kansai region were making 'sukiyaki' for which beef was broiled before seasoning it with sugar, soy sauce and broth.

sen.j: 次第に関東でもこちらの「すき焼き」という呼称が定着していったようである。
sen.e: Then, the name of sukiyaki seemed to have gradually transferred and settled into the Kanto region.
Gradually people in the Kanto region began to use the term "sukiyaki" as well.
Gradually people in the Kanto region began to use the term 'sukiyaki' as well.

sen.j: 横浜にはぶつ切り牛肉を使い、適宜、割下を注ぎながら濃い味噌だれで炒りつけるように煮る牛鍋を供する名店がある。
sen.e: Now in Yokohama, there is a restaurant famous for its gyu-nabe using chunks of beef being basted in thick miso sauce (sauce of soybean paste) and sauted with warishita (stock of soy sauce, mirin and sugar) in a pot.

Now, in Yokohama, there is a restaurant famous for its gyu-nabe which uses chunks of beef basted in thick miso sauce (sauce from soybean paste) and sautéed with warishita (stock made from soy sauce, mirin and sugar) in a pot.
Now, in Yokohama, there is a restaurant famous for its gyu-nabe which uses chunks of beef basted in thick miso sauce (sauce from soybean paste) and sautéed with warishita in a pot.

sen.j: 幕末期、開港場の横浜では牛肉の煮売り屋台があった。
sen.e: At the end of the Edo Period, dishes of boiled beef were served in street stalls in the open port of Yokohama.
At the end of the Edo Period, boiled beef dishes were served at street stalls in the port of Yokohama.
At the end of the Edo period, boiled beef dishes were served at street stalls in the port of Yokohama.
sen.cmt: period を小文字にしました。

sen.j: ぼたん鍋の転用で、味噌煮込みであったらしい。
sen.e: They seem to have been the beef stew boiled in miso broth, which was a diversion of botan-nabe (a dish of wild boar meat cooked in a pot at the table.)
This dish seems to have been a beef stew boiled in miso broth, which was a derivation of botan-nabe (wild boar meat cooked in a pot at the table.)

sen.j: 明治初期の「牛屋（ぎゅうや）」の牛鍋もこうした味噌鍋が主流であったと思われる。
sen.e: Early in the Meiji Period, "gyuya" (a restaurant to serve beef dishes) were assumed to have sold mainly such miso-based gyu-nabe dishes.
Early in the Meiji Period, "gyuya" (restaurants that served beef dishes) were assumed to have sold mainly such miso-based gyu-nabe dishes.
Early in the Meiji period, 'gyuya' (restaurants that served beef dishes) were assumed to have sold mainly such miso-based gyu-nabe dishes.

sen.j: 先述のぶつ切り牛肉の味噌鍋の店も、こうした牛鍋のプロトタイプの名残りと見る事ができよう。
sen.e: The above mentioned miso-based dish of beef chunks may be regarded as a reminder of prototypes of these gyu-nabe cookings.
The above mentioned miso-based dish with beef chunks may be regarded as a remnant or prototype for other gyu-nabe style cooking.

tit.cmt: コロンを削除しました。

tit.j: 各地方での調理法の違い
tit.e: Different ways of cooking sukiyaki by regions:
Different ways of cooking sukiyaki by regions:
Different ways of cooking sukiyaki by regions
tit.cmt: コロンを削除しました。

sen.j: すき焼きは、日本国内各地方でその調理法に違いが見られる。
sen.e: The way of cooking sukiyaki differs depending on regions in Japan.
The way sukiyaki is cooked differs by region of Japan.
The way sukiyaki is cooked differs by region of Japan.

sen.j: 関東のすき焼きは明治に流行した牛鍋がベースになっており、出汁に醤油・砂糖・みりん・酒などの調味料を混ぜた割下をあらかじめ用意し、割下の中で牛肉を煮る。
sen.e: Sukiyaki in Kanto is based on gyu-nabe popularly eaten in the Meiji Period, where beaf is boiled in soup of warishita which has been prepared beforehand by mixing soup stock with shoyu (soybean sauce), sugar, mirin and sake wine.

Sukiyaki in the Kanto region is based on the gyu-nabe popularly eaten in the Meiji Period, where beef is boiled in a soup of warishita which has been prepared beforehand by mixing soup stock with shoyu (soy sauce), sugar, mirin and sake.

Sukiyaki in the Kanto region is based on the gyu-nabe popularly eaten in the Meiji period, where beef is boiled in a soup of warishita which has been prepared beforehand by mixing soup stock with soy sauce, sugar, mirin and sake.
sen.cmt: shoyu を削除し、soy sauce のみとしました。period を小文字にしました。

sen.j: 関西のものは文字通り牛肉を焼く料理で、肉が焼けたところに砂糖を乗せるかまぶし、醤油を直接加えて味付けをする。
sen.e: But in Kansai, sukiyaki means a dish to broil beef first, as the wording of sukiyaki means ("yaki" means broiing or grilling,) which is then flavored by dredging sugar and shoyu (soy sauce) direct on it.

However, in the Kansai region, sukiyaki refers to a dish in which beef is grilled first, as the phrase sukiyaki implies ("yaki" meaning to broil or grill,) which is then flavored by covering it with sugar and shoyu (soy sauce).

However, in the Kansai region, sukiyaki refers to a dish in which beef is grilled first, as the phrase sukiyaki implies ("yaki" meaning to broil or grill,) which is then flavored by covering it with sugar and soy sauce.
sen.cmt: shoyu を削除し、soy sauce のみとしました。

sen.j: 肉と水の出る野菜を同時に焼かない点、コンニャクなど肉を硬くする作用を持つものを一緒に焼かないことなど、関西の調理の手順には特徴がある。
sen.e: Procedures of cooking sukiyaki in Kansai are characteristic in that, for example, meat should not be broiled at the same time with vegetables which discharge water, that it should not be cooked together with paste of konjak which hardens meat, and so on..

The procedures for cooking sukiyaki in the Kansai region has various characteristics which include, boiling the meat and moist vegetables separately, as well as not cooking it together with Konjac paste which can harden the meat, and so forth.

The procedures for cooking sukiyaki in the Kansai region has various characteristics which include, boiling the meat and moist vegetables separately, as well as not cooking it together with Konjac paste which can harden the meat, and so forth.

sen.j: ただし、野菜など他の食材から出る水分と砂糖および醤油が混ざることを考慮して、牛肉が焼けた後に他の食材を加えて調理する地域もある。
sen.e: However, in some parts of Kansai region, people cook sukiyaki by putting vegetables and other ingredients in the pot only after beef is broiled, in mind that sugar and shoyu sauce will be mixed up with the water discharged from vegetables and other ingredients.

However, in some parts of the Kansai region, people prepare sukiyaki by putting vegetables and other ingredients in the pot only after the beef is cooked, with the intention of the sugar and shoyu sauce mixing together with the water from the vegetables and other ingredients.

However, in some parts of the Kansai region, people prepare sukiyaki by putting vegetables and other ingredients in the pot only after the beef is cooked, with the intention of the sugar and soy sauce mixing together with the water from the vegetables and other ingredients.
sen.cmt: shoyu を削除し、soy sauce のみとしました。

sen.j: 東西の食べ方の境界線は、愛知県豊橋市にあると言われる。
sen.e: A border line is said to exist in Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture, that divides two different ways of cooking sukiyaki in Kanto and Kansai.
It's said that there is a border in Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture, that divides the two different ways of cooking sukiyaki between the Kanto and Kansai regions.
It's said that there is a border in Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture, that divides the two different ways of cooking sukiyaki between the Kanto and Kansai regions.

sen.j: 現在では割下を万能調味料として売り出していることもあり、その境界は明確ではなくなってきている。
sen.e: Nowadays, however, such a border line has become unclear since warishita soup is commonly sold in the market as an all-purpose seasoning agent.
Nowadays, however, this border has become unclear due to warishita soup being commonly sold in markets as an all-purpose seasoning.
Nowadays, however, this border has become unclear due to warishita soup being commonly sold in markets as an all-purpose seasoning.

sen.j: 北海道や新潟県ではその昔、牛肉ではなく豚肉を使うことが一般的だった。
sen.e: In Hokkaido and Niigata Prefecture, people used to cook pork instead of beef in sukiyaki.
In Hokkaido and Niigata Prefecture, people used to use pork in Sukiyaki instead of beef.
In Hokkaido and Niigata Prefecture, people used to use pork in Sukiyaki instead of beef.

sen.j: これはかつてこの地域では牛肉が高価だったせいもあり、食べる習慣があまりなかったためである。
sen.e: This was because beef had once priced so expensive in those areas that people were less accustmed to eat it.
This was because beef was once so expensive in those areas that people were less accustomed to eating it.
This was because beef was once so expensive in those areas that people were less accustomed to eating it.

sen.j: しかし、比較的安価に牛肉が提供されるようになった現在では牛肉を使う場合が多い。
sen.e: Today, however, people often use beef for sukiyaki, which is now available at comparatively cheap prices in the market.
Today, however, people often use beef for sukiyaki, which is now available at comparatively cheap prices in the market.
Today, however, people often use beef for sukiyaki, which is now available at comparatively cheap prices in the market.

sen.j: また滋賀では鶏肉で食べる習慣もある。
sen.e: In Shiga Prefecture, there is also a custom to eat chicken meat in sukiyaki.
In Shiga Prefecture, it is also sometimes customary to use chicken meat in sukiyaki.
In Shiga Prefecture, it is also sometimes customary to use chicken meat in sukiyaki.

sen.j: 入れる野菜も、地方によってはモヤシを入れたりジャガイモを入れたりと様々である。
sen.e: Also, vegetables used as ingredients for sukiyaki are different by regions, like moyashi (bean sprouts,) potato and so on.
Also, the vegetables used as ingredients for sukiyaki differ by region, like moyashi (bean sprouts), potato and so forth.
Also, the vegetables used as ingredients for sukiyaki differ by region, like moyashi (bean sprouts), potato and so forth.

tit.cmt: コロンを削除しました。

sen.j: 古川緑波のエッセイによると、焼けた肉は具材を溶き卵に潜らせて食べるのは関西発祥で、関東の牛鍋をベースとしたすき焼き店では、溶き卵を出す店は無かったらしい。
sen.e: According to an essay written by Roppa FURUKAWA, Kansai is the birthplace of the custom to eat broiled meat and ingredients after dipping them in a beated egg, and reportedly, there was no restaurant in Kanto to offer beaten egg for gyu-nabe based sukiyaki dishes.

According to an essay written by Roppa FURUKAWA, Kansai is the birthplace of the custom of eating grilled meat and other ingredients after dipping them in beaten eggs, and reportedly, there was no restaurant in the Kanto region that offered beaten eggs for gyu-nabe based sukiyaki dishes at the time.

According to an essay written by Roppa FURUKAWA, Kansai is the birthplace of the custom of eating grilled meat and other ingredients after dipping them in beaten eggs, and reportedly, there was no restaurant in the Kanto region that offered beaten eggs for gyu-nabe based sukiyaki dishes at the time.

sen.j: その後、関西のすき焼き店が関東に進出してきた時に、溶き卵を付けて食べる習慣も持ち込まれ、一般化したと言う。
sen.e: Later, when sukiyaki restaurants in Kansai expanded their business into Kanto, they brought with them the custom to eat sukiyaki with a beaten egg and made it generally accepted in Kanto.

Later, when sukiyaki restaurants in the Kansai region expanded their business into the Kanto region, they brought with them the custom of eating sukiyaki with beaten eggs and it later became generally accepted in the Kanto region.

Later, when sukiyaki restaurants in the Kansai region expanded their business into the Kanto region, they brought with them the custom of eating sukiyaki with beaten eggs and it later became generally accepted in the Kanto region.

sen.j: なぜとき卵が使われるようになったかと言うと具材をいきなり口にいれ火傷をしてしまわないようにと、ほどよい温度にしてから食べるようにしたためである。
sen.e: The reason why beaten eggs were used was to lower the temperature of hot ingredients before eating them and prevent a scald caused by putting hot ingredients direct into the mouth.
The reason why beaten eggs were used was to lower the temperature of hot ingredients before putting them into your mouth to prevent being scalded.
The reason why beaten eggs were used was to lower the temperature of hot ingredients before putting them into your mouth to prevent being scalded.

Japanese sake (rice wine) may be added to dilute the warishita stock if it becomes too strong.

tit.e: Chicken eggs for a side dish:
tit.cmt: 原文wikiを参照し、「溶き卵」に相当する訳を追加しました。

sen.cmt: 文頭のスペースを削除しました。

tit.cmt: コロンを削除しました。

sen.j: 材料は食べやすい大きさに切っておく。
sen.e: Beforehand, ingredients must be cut into proper sizes for eating.
Beforehand, ingredients should be cut into proper sizes for ease of eating.
Beforehand, ingredients should be cut into proper sizes for ease of eating.

sen.j: 熱したすき焼き鍋に割下を適量入れ、肉や野菜と共に煮る。
sen.e: Put an adequate quantity of warishita stock into a heated pot for sukiyaki, and boil meats together with vegetables in it.
Put an adequate quantity of warishita stock into a heated pot for sukiyaki, then boil the meat and vegetables together in it.
Put an adequate quantity of warishita stock into a heated pot for sukiyaki, then boil the meat and vegetables together in it.

sen.j: 割下を入れる量は、味の濃い割下なら鍋底が隠れる位の少量でよい。
sen.e: Quantity of strong warishita may be so small as to barely cover whole base of pot.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: If you are using strong warishita stock the amount used may be so little as to barely cover bottom of pot.
If you are using strong warishita stock the amount used may be so little as to barely cover bottom of pot.

sen.j: 味が薄めの割下なら通常の鍋と同程度の量を入れる。
sen.e: If its taste is rather plain, feed about the same quantity of warishita stock as usually used for ordinary cookings in a pot.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: If the stock isn't as strong, use about the same quantity of warishita stock as would ordinarily be used for cooking in a pot.
If the stock isn't as strong, use about the same quantity of warishita stock as would ordinarily be used for cooking in a pot.

sen.j: 火が通ったら溶き卵にくぐらせて食べる。
sen.e: When meats and ingredients are cooked through, take them out of pot and dip them into a beated egg before eating.
When the meat and other ingredients are cooked thoroughly, take them out of the pot and dip them into a beaten egg before eating.
When the meat and other ingredients are cooked thoroughly, take them out of the pot and dip them into a beaten egg before eating.

sen.j: シメには茹でたうどんを入れ、旨みの凝縮された汁を味付けをし直した後、染み込ませて食べる。
sen.e: In closing, put boiled noodles into the pot and make the condensed soup sink into the noodles after adjusting its taste.
To finish, put boiled noodles into the pot and allow the flavor of the remaining soup to soak into them before eating.
To finish, put boiled noodles into the pot and allow the flavor of the remaining soup to soak into them before eating.

sen.j: 味付けの濃い割下では辛くなるだけなので要注意。
sen.e: Be careful that, if the warishita soup has still a strong flavor, it may give the noodles nothing but a hot flavor.
Keep in mind that if the warishita soup still has a strong flavor, it may simply make the noodles spicy.
Keep in mind that if the warishita soup still has a strong flavor, it may simply make the noodles spicy.

sen.j: なお、北大路魯山人によると「まずは肉だけを煮て食べ、次にザクだけ、というように交互に食べるとよい」という。
sen.e: Rosanjin KITAOJI recommended "to eat alternately, first only meats and then only zaku (ingredients other than meats)"
Rosanjin KITAOJI recommended "to alternate between eating the meat and the zaku (ingredients other than meats)"
Rosanjin KITAOJI recommended 'to alternate between eating the meat and the zaku (ingredients other than meats).'

sen.j: また、「酒呑みのためのすき焼きには砂糖は入れない」のだそうである。
sen.e: Also he said that "no sugar is added to sukiyaki that is arranged especially for sake drinkers."
He also said "no sugar should be added to sukiyaki prepared especially for sake drinkers."
He also said 'no sugar should be added to sukiyaki prepared especially for sake drinkers.'

tit.cmt: セミコロンを削除しました。

sen.j: 野菜や豆腐などの具材は食べやすい大きさに切っておく。
sen.e: In advance, vegetables, tofu (soybean curds) and other ingredients must be cut into proper sizes for eating.
Beforehand, the vegetables, tofu and other ingredients should be cut into proper sizes for ease of eating.
Beforehand, the vegetables, tofu and other ingredients should be cut into proper sizes for ease of eating.

sen.j: すき焼き鍋を熱して牛脂をひき、牛肉を入れて火が通るまで焼く。
sen.e: Grease a heated pot by a chip of beef fat, and then put and broil beef in it until the beef becomes cooked through.
Grease a heated pot with a lump of beef fat, then grill the beef in it until it is thoroughly cooked.
Grease a heated pot with a lump of beef fat, then grill the beef in it until it is thoroughly cooked.

sen.j: 焼けた肉の上に砂糖をのせ、その上から料理酒、醤油を入れる。
sen.e: Dredge sugar on the broiled beef, then pour cooking liquor and soy sauce on them.
Spread sugar on the grilled beef, then pour cooking liquor and soy sauce over it.
Spread sugar on the grilled beef, then pour cooking liquor and soy sauce over it.

sen.j: 野菜や豆腐など、牛肉以外の具を入れる。
sen.e: Put into the pot vegetables, tofu curds and other ingredients except beef.
Put the other ingredients into the pot, including vegetables and tofu.
Put the other ingredients into the pot, including vegetables and tofu.

sen.j: 水分は野菜から出るが、ここで好みにより水や日本酒、昆布出汁を追加しても良い。
sen.e: Though some quantity of water will be discharged from vegetables, you may adjust the flavor by adding further water, Japanese sake wine or seaweed broth, as you like.
Though some quantity of water may be released from the vegetables, you can adjust the flavor by adding more water, Japanese sake (rice wine) or seaweed broth, as you like.
Although some quantity of water may be released from the vegetables, you can adjust the flavor by adding more water, Japanese sake or seaweed broth, as you like.
sen.cmt: 日本酒 既出のため、補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 器に入れた溶き卵にくぐらせて食べる。
sen.e: After dipping in a beaten egg, you may eat the broiled beef and other ingredients.
The grilled beef and other ingredients are eaten after being dipped in beaten eggs.
The grilled beef and other ingredients are eaten after being dipped in beaten eggs.

sen.j: これは関東風と同じである。
sen.e: This is done in the same way as the Kanto-style.
This is how sukiyaki is eaten according to the Kanto-style.
This is how sukiyaki is eaten according to the Kanto-style.

tit.j: 坂本九のSUKIYAKI （上を向いて歩こう）
tit.e: SUKIYAKI song of Kyu SAKAMOTO (Uewo Muite Aruko):
SUKIYAKI song by Kyu SAKAMOTO (Uewo Muite Aruko):
SUKIYAKI song by Kyu SAKAMOTO (Uewo Muite Aruko)
tit.cmt: コロンを削除しました。

sen.j: アメリカ合衆国では、1963年に坂本九の曲『上を向いて歩こう』が大ヒットした。
sen.e: This song of Kyu SAKAMOTO with a lyric of "Uewo Muite Aruko" (literally, let's walk looking upward) scored a big hit in the United States of America in 1963.
This song by Kyu SAKAMOTO with the lyric "Uewo Muite Aruko" (literally, let's walk looking upward) was a big hit in the United States of America in 1963.
This song by Kyu SAKAMOTO with the lyric "Uewo Muite Aruko" (literally, let's walk looking upward) was a big hit in the United States of America in 1963.

sen.j: 曲名の由来はすき焼きが日本を代表する料理であり、またレコード会社の社長が日本で食べた「スキヤキ」が旨かったからであるとされる。
sen.e: This song was titled SUKIYAKI, the reason of which is attributed to the fact that sukiyaki is the representative cuisine of Japan as well as the fact that the head of record company could enjoy eating delicious "sukiyaki" in Japan.

The reason the song was titled SUKIYAKI, is attributed to the fact that sukiyaki is a dish representative of Japan, as well as the fact that the head of the record company enjoyed eating delicious "sukiyaki" in Japan.

The reason the song was titled SUKIYAKI, is attributed to the fact that sukiyaki is a dish representative of Japan, as well as the fact that the head of the record company enjoyed eating delicious 'sukiyaki' in Japan.

sen.j: 同曲は、1963年6月15日にはビルボードおよびキャッシュボックスの第1位にランキングされた。
sen.e: This song was ranked as No.1in both magazines, the Billboard and the Cash Box on June 15, 1963.
This song was ranked No. 1by two magazines, "Billboard" and "Cash Box" on June 15th, 1963.
sen.cmt: reword. Unclear if "the" is part of the titles of these magazines.
sen.e: This song was ranked No. 1 by two magazines, Billboard and Cash Box on June 15, 1963.
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 日本人の歌がアメリカでヒットチャートのNo.1になったのは、現時点でこの曲だけである。
sen.e: At present, this is the only one Japanese song that was ranked as No.1 in the charts in the U.S.A.
Even today, this is the only Japanese song to ever rank No. 1 in the charts in the U.S.A.
Even today, this is the only Japanese song to ever rank No. 1 in the charts in the U.S.A.

tit.cmt: コロンを削除しました。

sen.j: しらたきの近くに肉を置くと、しらたきに含まれているカルシウム分のために肉が硬くなるので、これらの具は離して置いたほうが良い。
sen.e: Such ingredients as shirataki (white stringy food made from konjac starch) had better be placed apart from meat in a pot, because calcium contained in shirataki causes the nearby meat hardened.

Certain ingredients such as shirataki (white stringy food made from konjac starch) should be set apart from the meat in the pot, because calcium contained in the shirataki causes the nearby meat to harden.

Certain ingredients such as shirataki (white stringy food made from konjac starch) should be set apart from the meat in the pot, because calcium contained in the shirataki causes the nearby meat to harden.

sen.j: 大晦日や正月にすき焼きを食べる家庭があるが、これは豪華な食事の象徴のようである。
sen.e: Some households in Japan are said to take sukiyaki dishes on New Year's Eve or on New Year's Day, in which case sukiyaki is seemingly regarded as a symbol of gorgeous cuisines.
Some households in Japan are said to have sukiyaki on New Year's Eve or on New Year's Day, in which case sukiyaki is seemingly regarded as a symbol of extravagant cuisine.
Some households in Japan are said to have sukiyaki on New Year's Eve or on New Year's Day, in which case sukiyaki is seemingly regarded as a symbol of extravagant cuisine.

sen.j: 沖縄県では大衆食堂のメニューにしばしば掲げられるが、これは鉄鍋で煮込みながら食べる本土のすき焼きとは異なる。
sen.e: In Okinawa Prefecture, sukiyaki is often listed on a menu of inexpensive eating places, but their sukiyaki is different from mainland's sukiyaki that is served in a cast-iron pot for broiing.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In Okinawa Prefecture, sukiyaki is often listed on the menu at inexpensive eating locations, but their sukiyaki is different from the mainland's sukiyaki that is served in a cast-iron pot.
In Okinawa Prefecture, sukiyaki is often listed on the menu at inexpensive eating locations, but their sukiyaki is different from the mainland's sukiyaki that is served in a cast-iron pot.

sen.j: 沖縄のすきやきは、肉と野菜、豆腐を甘く煮合わせたものに生卵（あるいは目玉焼き）を乗せて平皿に盛った一品料理である。
sen.e: Sukiyaki in Okinawa is an a-la-carte dish made from meats, vegetables and tofu curds being sweetly boiled all together to be served on one plate with a topping of a raw egg (or an egg fried sunny-side up.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Sukiyaki in Okinawa is an a-la-carte dish made from meat, vegetables and tofu boiled together for sweetness and then served on a plate with a raw egg (or an egg fried sunny-side up.)
Sukiyaki in Okinawa is an a-la-carte dish made from meat, vegetables and tofu boiled together for sweetness and then served on a plate with a raw egg (or an egg fried sunny-side up.)

sen.j: これはハワイと同様に亜熱帯に属する沖縄県では、食卓で火を用いる鍋料理が発達しなかったことによる変化であると考えられる。
sen.e: It may be assumed that in Okinawa which belongs to a subtropical region, like Hawaii, such cookings as heated dishes in a pot at the table could hardly developed.
It's possible that in Okinawa which is in a subtropical region, similar to Hawaii, meals which require a large heated pot at the table were unlikely to be developed.
It's possible that in Okinawa which is in a subtropical region, similar to Hawaii, meals which require a large heated pot at the table were unlikely to be developed.

sen.j: アメリカでは日本料理の代表として良く知られていて人気がある。
sen.e: In the U.S., sukiyaki is popularly accepted as the representative dish of Japan.
In the U.S., sukiyaki is popularly known as a dish representative of Japan.
In the U.S., sukiyaki is popularly known as a dish representative of Japan.

sen.j: ただし生卵に対する抵抗は強いため、用いられないことが多い。
sen.e: However, raw eggs are often avoided due that the Americans have a strong resistance to the raw eggs.
However, the raw eggs are often excluded due to Americans having a strong dislike for raw eggs.
However, the raw eggs are often excluded due to Americans having a strong dislike for raw eggs.

sen.j: ハワイ州にはすき焼きから派生した「ヘッカ」と呼ばれる煮込み料理がある。
sen.e: Hawaiian people have a cuisine of boiled foods called "Hekka."
Hawaiian people have a dish made of boiled foods called "Hekka."
Hawaiian people have a dish made of boiled foods called 'Hekka.'

sen.j: これは日系移民が伝えて定着したもので、現地では牛肉ではなく鶏肉を用いるのが一般的である。
sen.e: This is a dish introduced by Japanese immigrants and settled in Hawaii, but it uses chicken instead of beef.
This is a dish introduced by Japanese immigrants that settled in Hawaii, however, it uses chicken instead of beef.
This is a dish introduced by Japanese immigrants that settled in Hawaii, however, it uses chicken instead of beef.

sen.j: タイ王国には「タイスキ」 (Thai Suki) という料理があるが、これはしゃぶしゃぶに近い料理である。
sen.e: In Thailand, there is a dish called "Thai Suki" (Thai-style sukiyaki,) which is, however, similar to shabu-shabu rather than sukiyaki.
In Thailand, there is a dish called "Thai Suki" (Thai-style sukiyaki,) which is, however, more similar to shabu-shabu than sukiyaki.
In Thailand, there is a dish called 'Thai Suki' (Thai-style sukiyaki,) which is, however, more similar to shabu-shabu than sukiyaki.

sen.j: 三谷幸喜のエッセイにもある話だが、すき焼きを「軽く炒めた肉に水を加え、醤油と砂糖と野菜類としらたきを入れて煮込んだ料理」と認識している人がかなりいる。
sen.e: As Koki MITANI described in his essay, a considerable number of people have an understanding of sukiyaki as a boiled cuisine of lightly broiled meat with additional water, soy sauce, sugar, vegetables and shirataki (white stringy food of konjac starch.)

As Koki MITANI described in his essay, a considerable number of people understand sukiyaki to be a dish of boiled or lightly grilled meat with added water, soy sauce, sugar, vegetables and shirataki (white stringy food made from konjac starch.)

As Koki MITANI described in his essay, a considerable number of people understand sukiyaki to be 'a dish in which meat is lightly grilled, then water is added and boiled together with sauce, sugar, vegetables and shirataki.'
sen.cmt: しらたき 既出のため、補足を削除しました。「肉を軽く炒めてから、他の具材を追加して煮込んだ料理」という表現に変更しました。

sen.j: この場合は従って、すき焼きが「焼けた」ではなく、「煮えた」と言う。
sen.e: But, in this case, sukiyaki should be quoted as "being boiled" instead of "being broiled or grilled."
In this case, the sukiyaki is "boiled" rather than "grilled."
In this case, the sukiyaki is 'boiled' rather than 'grilled.'

sen.j: 家庭で、割り下を作る（関東風）、砂糖をかける（関西風）などの手間を面倒臭がって、あるいは、時間が掛かるという理由から省いた結果である。
sen.e: This is a result of skipping the efforts to prepare warishita stock (in Kanto-style) or to dredge sugar (in Kansai-style) for the reason that such efforts are too troublesome or time-consuming.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This is due to skipping the preparation of warishita stock (in Kanto-style) or the layer of sugar (in Kansai-style) because it would be too troublesome or time-consuming.
This is due to skipping the preparation of warishita stock (in Kanto-style) or the layer of sugar (in Kansai-style) because it would be too troublesome or time-consuming.

sen.j: 極端な場合は、「牛脂で焼いた肉を水と醤油で煮たもの（野菜やしらたきの類は入っていない）」や「肉じゃがのジャガイモ抜き」がすき焼きだ、と子供が思い込まされるケースも多々有る。
sen.e: In an extreme case, innocent children are often taught to understand sukiyaki as "a boiled dish of meat (after being broiled with grease of beef fat) in hot water and soy sauce (without vegetables and shirataki,)" or "a dish of nikujaga (a sweetly boiled dish of meat and potato) with no potato cooked together."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In extreme cases, children are sometimes taught to understand sukiyaki to be "a boiled dish of meat (after being grilled with grease from beef fat) in hot water and soy sauce (without vegetables and shirataki,)" or "a dish of nikujaga (a sweet boiled dish of meat and potato) without the potato."

In extreme cases, children are sometimes taught to understand sukiyaki to be 'a boiled dish of meat (after being grilled with grease from beef fat) in hot water and soy sauce (without vegetables and shirataki,)' or 'a dish of nikujaga (a sweet boiled dish of meat and potato) without the potato.'

sen.j: 「煮たすき焼き」をすき焼きと思い込まされた人が上記のすき焼き（関東風、関西風を問わず）を見た時、別の料理であると認識してしまうケースもある。
sen.e: It sometimes happens that any person who are induced to believe in the "boiled sukiyaki" would identify the above mentioned original sukiyaki as a different cuisine, whether Kanto-style or Kansai-style it may be.

It sometimes happens that a person taught that this "boiled sukiyaki" is sukiyaki would identify the above mentioned original sukiyaki as a different dish altogether, regardless of it being Kanto-style or Kansai-style.

It sometimes happens that a person taught that this 'boiled sukiyaki' is sukiyaki would identify the above mentioned original sukiyaki as a different dish altogether, regardless of it being Kanto-style or Kansai-style.

sen.j: 煮たすき焼きを本来のすき焼きと区別して「すき煮」と言うこともある。
sen.e: Boiled sukiyaki may be called "sukini" in order to distinguish it from genuine sukiyaki.
This "boiled sukiyaki" may be called "sukini" in order to distinguish it from genuine sukiyaki.
This boiled sukiyaki may be called 'sukini' in order to distinguish it from genuine sukiyaki.
